Ask HN: What did you learn this year?
text:
Elixir: I finally learned Elixir/OTP, working with it full-time for data engineering related tasks. I learned that there was an entire ecosystem of mature data processing related libraries and frameworks. OTP is very impressive. It's very interesting how pipelines of chained calls utilize pattern-matching in function clauses and how some have rejected use of this pattern. Mock tests with Tesla http client was the biggest dissapointment thus far.

Terraform: Infrastructure as code is everywhere, now. I never cared to learn a proprietary configuration language for creating infrastructure resources, but am glad that I finally did put some effort into learning the fundamentals. It feels like we are at the beginning of the automation story with tools such as Terraform. Maybe AI-assisted tooling will come next, where natural language describing our intention will be all that is necessary, rather than a configuration language.

ChatGPT: I'm largely using it as a replacement for Google and StackOverflow. It's helped me write json parsers using the 'jq' command line utility, write regex patterns, write terraform config for AWS resources, and more. I wish the maximum output were longer. I didn't find code assistance accurate enough to rely on it too much.

How to best monetize collection of 8bit computers?
text: Good friend of mine do have great collection of 8bit computers. Apart from usual ones (Commodore, Sinclair…), there are lot of East European and similar model that are not frequent. He was thinking about some kind of museum, but I am looking for better solution, if any. Museums require large investment and usualy bring low revenue. Any idea or advice how to create better business out of it? Location would be Europe.
